conclusion: Understanding the geometry of the wire bent into a ν-shape with a 60° angle and each side of length l.
The wire is in a uniform magnetic field B, perpendicular to the plane, with current I flowing through it.
Force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by F = I L × B.
Direction of force on each segment is perpendicular to both the current and the magnetic field.
For each segment of length l, the force is F = I l B.
Forces on the two segments form a 60° angle; need to resolve these forces into components.
Each force F can be resolved into components: Fx = I l B cos(30°), Fy = I l B sin(30°).
Resultant force is found by adding vector components: F_resultant = √((2 I l B cos(30°))^2 + 0).
Magnitude of the resultant force is F_resultant = I l B √3.
